title.value: Long-term plasticity induces sparse and specific synaptic changes in a biophysically detailed cortical model
title.justification: The title of the paper is clearly stated at the beginning of the paper.
title.quote: Long-term plasticity induces sparse and specific synaptic changes in a biophysically detailed cortical model

extractions.description: This paper investigates the effects of long-term synaptic plasticity on a biophysically detailed cortical network model. It integrates a calcium-based model of functional plasticity into a large-scale cortical network, simulates its activity under in vivo-like conditions, and analyzes the sparse and highly specific changes in synaptic efficacy. The findings emphasize the specificity of plastic changes and their consequences for network stability and function.

type.justification: The paper involves simulation-based empirical investigations of synaptic plasticity in a detailed cortical microcircuit.
type.quote: Due to the limitations of available experimental techniques, investigating synaptic plasticity at the microcircuit level relies on simulation-based approaches.

name.justification: The primary focus of the paper is on understanding synaptic plasticity within a neuronal context and its implications for cortical microcircuits.
name.quote: Synaptic plasticity underlies the brain’s ability to learn and adapt.

name.justification: The study integrates and analyzes computational models of neuronal activity and plasticity.
name.quote: To overcome these limitations, we extended a previously published and validated large-scale cortical network model with a recently developed calcium-based model of functional plasticity between excitatory cells.

name.justification: The research investigates the behavior of neural systems under various conditions and stimuli.
name.quote: ..provided inputs through the thalamocortical fibers. Complex phenomena like plasticity are traditionally studied under controlled laboratory conditions...

name.justification: The model used in the study is explicitly identified as the calcium-based plasticity model described in Chindemi et al. (2022).
name.quote: To model long-term plasticity we integrated our recently published calcium-based plasticity model that was used to describe functional long-term potentiation and depression between pairs of pyramidal cells (PCs; Chindemi et al., 2022).

is_contributed.justification: The model has been integrated and extended within the context of this study to fit the simulation of the large-scale cortical network.
is_contributed.quote: We extended a previously published and validated large-scale cortical network model with a recently developed calcium-based model of functional plasticity between excitatory cells.

is_executed.justification: The model was executed for simulating the neuronal activity as described in the simulation setup.
is_executed.quote: To achieve a continuous readout of plastic changes in synaptic efficacy of millions of excitatory synapses, we used a biophysically detailed, large-scale cortical model of the rat non-barrel somatosensory cortex (nbS1).

is_compared.justification: The primary goal of the study was to observe the behavior of the model in isolation and not to compare its performance against other models.
is_compared.quote: In summary, we observed that ∼ 5% of synapses undergo long-term plasticity under realistic in vivo-like conditions in 10 minutes, and most of these synapses are on above-average firing rate L5 PC’s basal dendrites.

name.quote: The model improves on Markram et al. (2015) in terms of both anatomical, e.g., atlas based cell composition and placement (described in Reimann et al., 2022), and physiological properties, e.g., improved single cell models, multi-vesicular synaptic release, and layer-wise compensation for missing synapses (described in Isbister et al., 2023).
